search_input:
4.1.1 FLOOR . . . staking the claim of civilization on the raw ground, encoding usage and assuming decoration, the floor then accrues complexity in its section while simplifying its surface details. The textural details of previous occupants are kept intact. There is a map-like pattern on the concrete floor. It is a space of pure white. Most of the buildings in the world are structured today by three-dimensional frames, consisting of floor slabs supported by beams, beams supported by columns, columns supported by foundations, and foundations sitting on the earth. The beams and columns, usually set at the corners of a rectangular grid, are made out of steel or reinforced concrete; the floor slabs, most of the time, of reinforced concrete.

*The arrangement of these elements allows for flexibility in design, enabling the creation of various architectural styles and layouts. As a result, the floor becomes a canvas for artistic expression, a space for people to leave their mark and tell their story. In this sense, the floor is not just a physical surface but also a symbolic one, bearing the weight of history and the stories of those who have walked upon it.*

As a result, the floor becomes a canvas for artistic expression, a space for people to leave their mark and tell their story. In this sense, the floor is not just a physical surface but also a symbolic one, bearing the weight of history and the stories of those who have walked upon it.
